newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: Greece seen unblocking EU funds for Turkey.
newsitem.headline: Greece seen unblocking EU funds for Turkey.

text.p: European Union foreign ministers meet on Tuesday hoping Greece will finally agree to unblock 375 million Ecus ($424 million) in aid to help Turkey adapt to a customs union with the bloc.

A spokesman for the Dutch presidency of the EU told reporters Athens was expected finally to give the go-ahead to the aid on Tuesday, although the Greek EU ambassador had refused to do so a day ahead of time at a meeting with his colleagues.
"The presidency is optimistic," the Dutch spokesman said.
The aid had been promised to Ankara to help it meet the increased competition posed by the customs union which entered into force with the EU at the beginning of 1996.
In the absence of the aid Turkey says it has felt little benefit from the deal.
Athens has taken its stand in response to what it sees as a lack of progress by Ankara on human rights and in the belief it is threatening Greek territorial integrity.
The two sides nearly came to war over a deserted islet in the Aegean Sea last year.
Greece's change of heart responds to what it sees as solidarity from its European partners.
